MERS-CoV nsp1 and SARS-CoV nsp1 only targeted RNAs that are translationally competent for degradation. unlike SARS-CoV nsp1, which is localized exclusively in the cytoplasm (11, 15), MERS-CoV nsp1 was distributed in both the nucleus and cytoplasm (36) the inability of MERS-CoV nsp1 to inhibit the translation of mRNAs of cytoplasmic origin suggests that MERS-CoV nsp1 does not use the components of the core translational machinery to gain access to translating mRNAs. this suggests that MERS-CoV nsp1 does not utilize the components of the core translational machinery to gain access to translating mRNAs. MERS-CoV nsp1 selectively targets nucleus-derived mRNAs for translation inhibition and mRNA degradation. nsp1 inhibited host protein synthesis and induced degradation of endogenous host mRNAs even in the presence of ActD, which prevents synthesis of new mRNAs. these data have important implications for the regulation of viral gene expression in MERS-CoV-infected cells. we hypothesize that the cytoplasmic origin of viral mRNAs facilitates their escape from MERS-CoV nsp1-induced translation inhibition allowing the efficient production of viral proteins. we speculate that the degradation of endogenous host mRNAs by MERS-CoV nsp1 indirectly facilitates the translation of exogenously delivered mRNAs in the future studies to examine the contribution of host mRNA degradation activity of MERS-CoV nsp1 on viral mRNA translation in MERS-CoV-infected cells are warranted.
